THAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. John Lloyd
Address: Unit 3, SASK.
Birthplace: England, Herefordshire, Farm.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1904.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Homestead.
Where had you been living before that? England, Farm home.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Husband & usually hired men.
How far was it to your nearest store? In 1906: 45 miles; 1906: 2 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Mail delivery came quite often.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Same as today except fresh fruit.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal, Homestead, Purify, etc.
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. Bag - 4.5 lb. From 1912: 360 lb. the way fell.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About 2.25.
How much did you use Graham flour? little.
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? After 1918.
How far away? 15 mi. That year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 75¢ - usually bought 80 lb. Bag.
What other grain products did you use? None.
Cornmeal? 20 lb. Bag.
Whole wheat? 100 lb. Bag.
Farin? 100 lb. Bag.
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No.
How did you grind it?

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

We lived just as well in those days as today - we had vegetables a little more now - like fresh lettuce, cabbage, celery.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? ...................... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

1905. Ourself, two nieghbours.

Roast chicken, all the usuals - real feast - but have forgotten details.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No - Usually had lots to sell -

1934 to 38 was hardest experience - but had lots of food short of money for store goods.

1934 to 38 was hardest experience - but hate it if forced

short of money for store goods
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

On farms today - no bread is being baked or butter made. Bread comes from large bakeries in Edmonton or Saskatoon - & butter from Creamery store - odd can cream shipped - but only enough cows are milked to keep home supplied.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still can a lot of fruits. Vegetables also quite a lot from our orchard, but outside of this we try to do as little as possible in Farm House - Wheat from Cold Storage - Buy nearly all cakes. Burn Ele - except Pies.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

After the first few years, we had rather a large home - with children, help in house, & 3 extra men on farm - so we usually bought things in large quantities, so we were seldom caught short of anything. We also had enough money when we came out here, to set us up farming right away, indeed although our first home was a sod shack for 1st 2 years - we had quite a good time homesteading. First year mail twice goods had to come from Battleford 45 miles by railroad at Saskatoon (150) yet commerce in other was always going in bringing mail supplies - a local store P.O. Church was built in 1906.
22. Plants and other details from your early experiences of buying, growing, and harvesting fruits in your area during pioneer days in Eastern Canada.

Include items not covered above, quality, methods of harvesting, etc.

If more space is needed, use back of this page.

After the first few years we had neither a large town or wide delivery, help in town, so we usually bought things in large quantities, so we were always caught short of anything, we also had enough money when we came out here, so we were farming right away under all the our first home was a sod shack for 1-2 years - we had quite a good farm homestead.

First year mail took a month to come from Bathford 45 miles.

A railroad at Faribault (19) yet enormous in olden days was always going on through our mail trails - a local store - P.O. Office was built in 1906.
